name: cucumis-sativus
definition: Cucumber  is a widely cultivated plant in the gourd family, Cucurbitaceae.
description:
Cucumber is a warm season, vining, annual plant in the gourd family, grown for its edible cucumber fruit.

Cucumber plants survive only one growing season and the vines can reach up to 5 meters in length.

The cucumber plant is a sprawling vine with large leaves and curling tendrils.

The plant may have 4 or 5 main stems from which the tendrils branch.

The hairy leaves have three to five pointed lobes, and the stem bears branched tendrils by which the plant can be trained to supports.

The cucumber fruit varies in shape but is generally a curved cylinder rounded at both ends.

It can reach up to 60 centimeters in length and 10 centimeters in diameter.

The five-petaled yellow flowers are unisexual and produce a type of berry known as a pepo.

Cucumbers are fruits but are used as vegetables.

Cucumbers are low in calories and contain a good amount of water and soluble fiber, making them ideal for promoting hydration and aiding in weight loss.

The nutritional value of the cucumber is low, but its delicate flavour makes it popular for salads and relishes.

Small fruits are often pickled.

The cucumber can be grown in frames or on trellises in greenhouses in cool climates and is cultivated as a field crop and in home gardens in warmer areas.

The heat requirement is one of the highest among the common vegetables, and the fruits can become bitter if exposed to uneven watering conditions.

The plants are susceptible to a number of bacterial and fungal diseases, including downy mildew, anthracnose, and Fusarium wilt.

Cucumber grows best in warm, subtropical climate, in sunny areas on a fertile, well-drained soil.

People cultivate cucumbers mostly as a source of food.

Some types of cucumber are cultivated in ornamental purposes.

In 2016, world production of cucumbers was 80.6 million tonnes, led by China with nearly 77% of the total.

Cultivation of cucumber started 3000 years ago on foothills of the Himalayas, likely in India, and it quickly spread to the rest of the world.

Cucumber was popular and often consumed type of vegetable in the ancient Egypt and Rome.

Records of cucumber cultivation appear in France in the 9th century, England in the 14th century, and in North America by the mid-16th century.

contextual.caption: Cucumber is a creeping vine that bears cucumiform fruits that are used as vegetables.

featured.caption: The cucumber plant produces yellow flowers that are 4 centimeters in diameter.

facts.name: Hermaphrodite or individual flowers
facts.value: Cucumber can produce hermaphrodite flowers (they contain both types of reproductive organs) or individual male and female flowers on the same plant (monoecious types). Bees and bumblebees are main pollinators of the flowers. Parthenocarpic types of cucumbers produce fruit without pollination. Some types of cucumbers are able to perform self-pollination.

facts.name: Contains 90% water
facts.value: Cucumber contains more than 90% of water. It is rich source of vitamins C and vitamins of the B group and minerals such as iron, magnesium, potassium, and phosphorus.

facts.name: Greatest manufacturer in the world
facts.value: China is the greatest manufacturer of cucumbers in the world. It produces 40 million tons of cucumbers annually (60% of globally consumed cucumbers).

facts.name: Annual plant
facts.value: Cucumber is an annual plant (it completes its life cycle in one year).

facts.name: Used in cosmetic industry
facts.value: Cucumber is used in cosmetic industry for the production of soaps, lotions, shampoos and fragrances.

facts.name: Bright yellow flowers
facts.value: Cucumber produces bright yellow flowers during the summer and early autumn.

facts.name: Efficient against scorpion bites
facts.value: Ancient Romans were using cucumbers in treatment of scorpion bites and bad eyesight. We know today that cucumbers reduce blood cholesterol level.

facts.name: Fruits after 8 to 10 weeks
facts.value: Fruit appears 8 to 10 weeks after planting. One plant produces 25 to 125 fruit.

facts.name: Three groups: slicing, pickling and burples
facts.value: All varieties of cucumbers can be divided in three major groups: slicing (large cucumbers with rough skin), pickling (small cucumbers that are used for pickling) and burpless (cucumbers without seed, with smooth skin).

facts.name: Usually consumed raw
facts.value: Cucumber is usually consumed raw (in the form of salads) or pickled. Young leaves, stem and seed are used in the Asian cuisine.

facts.name: Fruit is cylindrically-shaped
facts.value: Fruit of cucumber is cylindrically-shaped, 8 to 60 centimeters long and covered with green skin with white tubercles (bumps) on the surface. Pulp is whitish, crispy and filled with numerous seed.

facts.name: Large, triangular-ovate leaves
facts.value: Cucumber develops large, triangular-ovate leaves divided in three lobes. Leaves are light-green colored.

facts.name: Hairy, angled stem
facts.value: Cucumber has hairy, angled stem that can grow in the form of vine (that can reach 30 to 180 centimeters in height) or shrub (that spreads 60 to 90 square centimeters in diameter). Spiraling tendrils support the growth of vines by attaching to the nearby structures.

facts.name: Used to combat bad breath
facts.value: Slice of cucumber can kill bacteria responsible for the bad breath in only 30 seconds (when placed on the palate). Also, cucumber produces cooling effect when placed on the skin and it can extract excess water from the swollen areas.

related.definition: Zucchini is a type of summer squash that belongs to the pumpkin family.
Eggplant , aubergine  or brinjal  is a plant species in the nightshade family Solanaceae.
Capsicum is a genus of flowering plants in the nightshade family Solanaceae.
The tomato is the edible, often red, berry of the plant Solanum lycopersicum, commonly known as a tomato plant.
